Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I glanced at the clock, my phone buzzing with a reminder: “Don’t forget to vote today!” I had planned to go in the afternoon, since my schedule was light and the polls were open all day. Just as I was about to leave, my younger brother stormed into the living room, his face flushed with anger. He accused me of breaking a promise—apparently, I’d forgotten to help him with his college application, and the deadline was tonight. He demanded we talk it out, right now, to clear the air and fix things between us.

I could see how much it meant to him; he needed me to listen, to communicate openly and rebuild the trust we’d always shared. But the clock was ticking, and I knew if I waited too long, I might miss my chance to vote. My role as a sister pulled me one way, urging me to stay and resolve our conflict, while my responsibility as a voter tugged me in the other, reminding me of my civic duty. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the expectations of family and country, unsure which role to honor first.
